misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculation instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes the distance between two points using four coordinate inputs rather than reading a single numeric grade (0–100) and mapping it to a letter grade as specified.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional logic to output the corresponding letter grade (A–F) based on the provided ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade
Program reads four double values instead of a single grade
Program computes a square root of dx^2 + dy^2 instead of using conditionals to map numeric grades to letters
No conditional statements related to grade ranges 90-100, 80-89, etc.
Output reports a distance, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or confusing this problem with a different assignment (distance between two points) rather than the grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite main so it asks for one numeric grade (0–100), stores it in a variable, then uses if/else-if/else statements to print the correct letter grade based on the specified ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, prompts, variables, and computation match a standard distance-between-points problem and do not reference grades or letters at all.

evidence.note: Code reads four coordinates and computes a distance instead of reading a single grade and determining a letter grade via conditionals.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Assignment Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that solves an unrelated problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of implementing the required Grade Calculator. This indicates a complete failure to follow the assignment instructions or a severe mix-up in code submission.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have confused this required submission with a previous or different programming assignment involving distance calculation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to accept a single numeric grade (0-100) and use sequential conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine the corresponding letter grade (A-F) based on set boundaries.
symptoms: The program reads four floating-point numbers instead of one integer.
The program uses the 'Math.sqrt' function for distance calculation.
Conditional logic for grading (A/B/C/D/F) is completely absent.
The output is a distance value, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read or adhere to the specific problem statement (Q3. Grade Calculator) or file management/submission error.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem description for Q3 and disregard the supplied code. You must design a solution specifically for the Grade Calculator problem using input and conditional logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code explicitly solves the distance formula problem, rendering it 100% incorrect for the grade calculator assignment.

evidence.note: This code segment performs geometric calculation (distance) and input reading that is inconsistent with a grade calculator requirement.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved - Student implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points, which is a completely different problem. The code does not address the grade calculator requirements at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either copied code from a different assignment or misunderstood the problem entirely, believing they needed to calculate distance between points rather than convert numeric grades to letter grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges. This requires conditional logic to check the grade value, not distance calculations.
symptoms: Code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of performing grade conversion
No conditional statements checking grade ranges
No letter grade output
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' not related to grade calculation
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete misunderstanding of the assignment or submission of wrong file. The student may have mixed up submissions or not read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start by carefully re-reading the problem. Create a new program that reads one integer (0-100), then uses if-else statements to check which range the grade falls into and print the corresponding letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (distance between points) versus the assigned problem (grade conversion). There is no overlap in functionality.

evidence.note: The entire program solves the distance calculation problem, not the grade conversion problem. The input prompts, variable names, calculations, and output are all for distance between two points.
Class name indicates distance calculation problem, not grade conversion

related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, prompts, variables, and computation match a standard 'distance between two points' problem and contain no logic related to grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: Entire main method is dedicated to computing distance between two points with no input or output related to numeric or letter grades.
